tasks.task: Demonstrating advancements in weed control methods.
subtasks: Explain the principles of weed control (prevention, eradication, control, management).
Illustrate the evolution from traditional methods to modern machinery in weed management.

tasks.task: Detail historical and contemporary weed control techniques.
subtasks: Describe the oldest method, tillage, including its mechanisms (physical removal, root injury, stem pruning, seed burial).

Enumerate variations of tillage techniques (plowing, disking, harrowing, levelling), their distinct impacts on different weed types (annuals, biennials, perennials), and their role in promoting seed germination.
Highlight the continued relevance of hoeing for perennial weed control, examining its effectiveness, limitations, and cultural significance.

tasks.task: Explore specific manual and mechanical weed removal techniques.
subtasks: Define and demonstrate hand weeding using tools like khurpi or sickles, noting its precision and utility in selective weed control.
Describe digging practices for perennial weeds, emphasizing root and rhizome removal, and their impact on deep-rooted, persistent species.
Introduce sickling and moving practices, explaining their roles in controlling seed production and physical displacement of weeds.

tasks.task: Discuss natural and chemical weed control methods.
subtasks: Detail burning techniques (post-harvest in sugar cane fields), its advantages (economic, quick disposal), and considerations for its use.
Explain flooding as a weed control strategy, its principle (aerobic requirement), and effectiveness against hydrophytic (water-tolerant) weed species.

tasks.task: Assess the merits and demerits of mechanical weed control methods.
subtasks: Summarize the benefits (historical precedence, economic viability, coverage efficiency) of mechanical methods.
Identify limitations (labor intensity, potential crop damage, environmental considerations) associated with mechanical weed control.
